channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Arizona Legislature Will Consider Repeal of 1864 Abortion Law
item.description: Two Republican state senators have said they support scrapping the law, enough to ensure final passage of repeal.

item.title: Two Men Are Charged Over the Felling of the Sycamore Gap Tree
item.description: Seven months after the beloved tree in northern England was cut down, the police charged two men in their 30s with damaging the 200-year-old tree and part of Hadrian’s Wall.

item.title: Donald Trump just added another $1.8 billion to his Truth Social fortune—on paper
item.description: He now controls another 36 million shares, almost 65% of the company.

item.title: UnitedHealth’s CEO Slammed Over Cyberattack
item.description: Several lawmakers questioned whether the company had become so large — with tentacles in every aspect of the nation’s medical care — that the effects of the hack were outsize.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israel Softens Stance on Some Issues in Cease-Fire Talks, Officials Say
item.description: In the latest sign that it is willing to make concessions, Israel has proposed allowing displaced Palestinians to return to northern Gaza, two Israeli officials said.

item.title: Japan has had so many bear attacks in the past year it’s turning to AI to act as a warning system
item.description: More than 200 people have been injured.

item.title: Federal Money Is All Over Milwaukee. Biden Hopes Voters Will Notice.
item.description: White House officials have barnstormed Wisconsin to make the connection between big changes and their signature laws.

item.title: Blinken Meets With Netanyahu, Hoping to Stave Off Rafah Assault
item.description: President Biden is pushing Hamas to release some hostages for a six-week cease-fire, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says he will do a major assault in Rafah “with or without” a deal.

item.title: Chase IHG One Rewards Business Premier card ups its welcome bonus—Ends soon
item.description: Chase announced new welcome bonuses for its IHG One Rewards consumer credit cards. New cardholders can earn up to 165,000 bonus points, depending on which card they choose.

item.title: Job Openings and Hiring Are at a 3-Year Ebb
item.description: March data showed a cooling labor market, but layoffs remain low. The overall trend is likely to be welcomed by Federal Reserve policymakers.

item.title: Record Number of Writers Were Jailed Globally in 2023, PEN America Says
item.description: For the first time, China has more than 100 incarcerated writers, and Israel and Russia entered the list of the 10 countries with the most imprisoned writers.

item.title: Outdated laws prevent gig economy workers from getting benefits. This pilot program shows the path forward
item.description: Benefits for app-based workers can be flexible, portable, and proportional to the hours they put in.

item.title: His Book Was Repeatedly Banned. Fighting For It Shaped His Life.
item.description: “The Chocolate War,” published 50 years ago, became one of the country’s most challenged books. Its author, Robert Cormier, spent years fighting attempts to ban it — like many authors today.

item.title: Palestinians in Gaza Express Gratitude for U.S. Campus Protests
item.description: The protests have come at a fearful time for Palestinians in Rafah, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowing to launch a ground invasion of the city.

item.title: Bumble, the dating app where women make the first move, is rolling out a feature where men get an ‘opening move’
item.description: The “opening moves” feature will be an optional one.
